newsitem.title: USA: US Senate tax outline has cap gains cut to 20 pct.
newsitem.headline: US Senate tax outline has cap gains cut to 20 pct.

text.p: A broad outline of proposals for the Senate Finance Committee's tax bill included a capital gains tax cut to 20 percent from the current maximum of 28 percent for individuals.
The discussion paper, obtained by Reuters, was distributed to senators and makes no mention of a reduction in the capital gains tax for corporations.

Senate Finance Committee Chairman William Roth, a Delaware Republican, planned to unveil his tax bill next week. The discussion paper was described as the direction the bill was taking but specifics were still being worked out.

The House Ways and Means Committee early Friday approved tax legislation that included a similar capital gains tax cut for individuals, but also a corporate capital gains tax rate reduction to 30 percent from the current 35 percent.
Any differences between the House and Senate tax bills must be worked out before the legislation can be enacted.
The draft of the Senate Finance Committee proposal would also not impose a capital gains tax on profits up to $500,000 for couples made on the sale of a home.
The Senate Finance plan included expanding Individual Retirement Accounts, which has been a priority for Roth.

The discussion draft included a proposed $500 per child tax credit that was given an estimated cost of $83 billion over five years. That would be a higher cost than the $71 billion in the House Ways and Means Committee bill.
The child credit would be allowed for children under age 17 and parents with children aged 13-16 would be required to deposit the credit into an education account.
The proposal would also allow a $250 per child credit for children under age 13 this year.
A new nonrefundable 50 percent tax credit for up to $3,000 of tuition expenses for higher education would be allowed, which appeared similar to a provision in the House tax bill.
A proposal for estate tax relief would phase in a higher threshold where the inheritance tax kicks in to $1 million from the current $600,000.
